docs.lead_paragraph: Odd as it may seem, George E. Pataki, the Republican governor of New York, appears to be accomplishing one of Hillary Rodham Clinton's most treasured goals. Senator Clinton has frequently said that the most important lesson she learned from her failed efforts to secure universal health insurance during her husband's tenure as president was that health care reform had to come one step at a time. In winning approval this week from the federal government to offer a new health insurance program for the working poor, New York became the only state in the country trying that approach.

headline.main: Pataki Winning Wider Health Care, a Step at a Time

docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer analysis of New York State's health insurance program for working poor; Family Health Plus will provide free health insurance for families and single adults earning too much to qualify for Medicaid; this is first time state has extended this type of program to adults without children; Tommy Thompson, secretary of health and human services, announces program with Gov George Pataki and offers lavish praise; analysis notes similarity of program to one proposed by Hillary Clinton during her senate campaign; says program is certain to be model for other states (M)
docs.snippet: Odd as it may seem, George E. Pataki, the Republican governor of New York, appears to be accomplishing one of Hillary Rodham Clinton's most treasured goals.    Senator Clinton has frequently said that the most important lesson she learned from her...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Legislators Seek Way to Restore Prenatal Care for Immigrants'' (news article, May 24): The plight of undocumented women needing prenatal care should serve to highlight the situation faced by thousands of legal immigrants of all ages who cannot receive Medicaid, including the elderly. Welfare reform prohibits legal immigrants entering the country after August 1996 from Medicaid coverage for the first five years after arrival.
docs.abstract: Igal Jellinek letter comments on May 24 article on efforts of legislators to restore prenatal care for undocumented aliens
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Legislators Seek Way to Restore Prenatal Care for Immigrants'' (news article, May 24):    The plight of undocumented women needing prenatal care should serve to highlight the situation faced by thousands of legal immigrants of...

docs.lead_paragraph: New York's largest union of health care workers and an association of 67 hospitals and nursing homes will begin contract talks today that both sides say will be unusually difficult because so many hospitals are operating in the red. ''It's going to be a lot tougher than usual because of the problems of hospital finance,'' said Bruce McIver, president of the hospitals' association, which includes Beth Israel, New York Presbyterian, Montefiore, Mount Sinai, St. Luke's-Roosevelt and St. Vincent. ''We are broke, and the union's expectations are beyond the pale.''

headline.main: Hospitals, Crying Poverty, To Start Talks With Union

docs.abstract: New York's largest union of health care workers 1199/SEIU, New York's Health and Human Service Union and an association of 67 hospitals and nursing homes will begin contract talks that both sides say will be unusually difficult because so many hospitals are operating at deficit; contract does not expire until November, but talks are beginning early because it is expected to be difficult to arrive at agreement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Internal documents from the New York Life Insurance Company raise more questions about how the company handled the nest egg of its employees and whether it used those funds to bolster its mutual fund business. The documents, disclosed in connection with an employee lawsuit, show that a New York Life executive served from 1993 to 2000 as the president of New York Life's mutual fund business while also serving as investment adviser to the company's pension fund.

headline.main: More Queries on Insurer's Handling of Its Pensions

docs.abstract: Internal documents from New York Life Insurance Co raise more questions about how company handled employees' pensions and whether it used those funds to bolster its mutual fund business; documents, disclosed in connection with employee lawsuit, show that Linda Livornese served from 1993 to 2000 as president of New York Life's mutual fund business while also serving as investment adviser to company's pension fund; lawyer leading lawsuit says dual role posed conflict of interest; New York Life continues to contest suit and says that Livornese served merely in advisory capacity (M)
docs.snippet: Internal documents from the New York Life Insurance Company raise more questions about how the company handled the nest egg of its employees and whether it used those funds to bolster its mutual fund business.    The documents, disclosed in...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush and Pataki administrations have reached an agreement that permits New York to begin providing medical coverage to 600,000 uninsured New Yorkers, according to state and federal officials involved in the negotiations. New York officials have been lobbying the federal government for more than a year to approve a state plan to provide such coverage directly to low-income New Yorkers using a combination of federal Medicaid money and state and local money.

headline.main: U.S. and Albany Agree to Provide Health Benefits to Uninsured Poor

docs.abstract: Bush and Pataki administrations reach agreement permitting New York to begin providing medical coverage to 600,000 uninsured New Yorkers; new health insurance program will bring into managed care companies low-income adults who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid benefits but do not receive medical coverage from employers; is expected to cost $1.1 billion in next three-and-a-half years; state has received sought-after approval to use Medicaid to pay for it (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush and Pataki administrations have reached an agreement that permits New York to begin providing medical coverage to 600,000 uninsured New Yorkers, according to state and federal officials involved in the negotiations.    New York officials...

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal program to protect patients from incompetent doctors is failing because health maintenance organizations and hospitals rarely report those doctors to the government as they are required to do, federal investigators say. Under federal law, H.M.O.'s and hospitals are supposed to inform the government of any disciplinary actions taken against doctors for incompetence or misconduct.

headline.main: INEPT PHYSICIANS ARE RARELY LISTED AS LAW REQUIRES

docs.abstract: Federal investigators say program to protect patients from incompetent doctors is failing because health maintenance organizations and hospitals rarely report them to government as required by law; inspector general of Department of Health and Human Services reports that in last decade 84 percent of HMO's and 60 percent of hospitals never reported single adverse action to government; from 1990 to 1999, while managed care became dominant form of health care in US covering more than 100 million Americans, HMO's reported only 715 adverse actions; low level of reporting occurred even though tens of thousands of Americans die each year because of medical errors (M)
docs.snippet: A federal program to protect patients from incompetent doctors is failing because health maintenance organizations and hospitals rarely report those doctors to the government as they are required to do, federal investigators say.    Under federal...

docs.lead_paragraph: To Celia Talavera, a housekeeper at an oceanfront hotel here, the passage of an ordinance raising the minimum wage to $10.50 in coastal sections of the city means the chance to save a little money to send her children to college. But Jeremiah Zinger, an actor working the lunch shift at Ocean Avenue Seafood, says the ordinance could cost him his day job because the restaurant's general manager is considering closing for lunch rather than paying the higher wage.

headline.main: 'Living Wage' Ordinance Both Delights And Divides

docs.abstract: Santa Monica City Council passes one of country's most extensive 'living wage' laws, requiring that businesses with annual gross revenues of $5 million or more in city's coastal and downtown tourism areas pay workers at least $10.50 per hour beginning in July 2002 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The education of new mothers at the Children's Hospital of Buffalo has long included instruction in breast-feeding and the importance of using car seats. But these days, during the tender, joyful hours after a baby's birth, the orientation in the maternity ward here has an additional, sobering element: a video about one of the most lethal forms of child abuse, violently shaking an infant, along with the request that parents sign an affidavit saying that they understand the risk.

headline.main: A Simple Video Finds Success Against Shaken Baby Abuse

docs.abstract: Video warning about dangers of shaking infants proves to be a successful part of education of new mothers at Children's Hospital of Buffalo; in six years before program began, there were 6.5 reported cases of forcible shaking per year on average; in two years after program's introduction, average dropped to 1.5, excluding babies born before program began (M)
